div.p: 1. VI. Friday.

The Chevalier Friederichsthal, attached to the Austrian legation, is going on an excursion in the course of which he intends to visit Boston— I had yesterday written Letters of introduction for him to President Quincy and to Edward Everett which I had promised him, and also one to my Son, which I gave him this morning. In an hour’s conversation with me he told me that he had last Summer visited and traversed the Islands of St. Domingo, Jamaica and Cuba, with the purpose of observing attentively the relative condition of the population in the three different states of long continued freedom, of Slavery and of recent emancipation. It was apparent that the result of these observations was very unfavourable to African, for his great admiration was concentrated on the flourishing condition of Cuba, his anticipations quite unpromising to Jamaica—and his severest animadversions reserved for Saint Domingo. He promised to send me his comparative statistical tables for the three islands which he did this Evening— They fully confirmed my expectations.— His visit detained me so that I found the clerk reading the Journal of yesterday, when I entered the House— Briggs moved to go instanter into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the appropriation Bill; which was done after postponing at the motion of John W. Jones, the report of the select Committee upon the brawl between Bynum and Rice Garland till next Monday— Casey took the Chair of the Committee— Stanly had the floor upon an amendment which he proposed to offer to the appropriations for the public buildings after the rejection of the amendments proposed by Petrikin, which he considered as certain— I could stand this no longer— I rose and asked if Jones, Chairman of the ways and means seriously intended to persist in opposing Petrikin’s amendment—to stop the work upon the public buildings, and to leave the workmen partly unpaid for the wages they had already earned? Jones with some faltering at first avowed that he did; but afterwards worked round to a consent that the appropriation should be increased to 60000 dollars on the Treasury building, to pay the workmen their wages already earned. I gave him a volley for resisting any part of Petrikin’s amendment— He attempted to divert the attention of the Committee to my overheated manner—talked of the shin-plasters of my favourite institutions, and said he supposed I wanted an entering wedge to increase the appropriation for the custom house at Boston— I replied to him with an abated vehemence of manner— Govr Lincoln, Waddy Thompson and Hunt aided me with argument— Stanly consented to withdraw his amendment if Jones would accept the two amendments of Petrikin, which Jones however refused—but upon taking the question by tellers there was a large majority for Petrikin’s amendments— In the course of the Evening Ogle made his second Speech on the furnishing of the President’s House; and replied with extreme severity to some animadversions of Governor Lincoln upon his former Speech— Lincoln now made an instantaneous highly spirited and triumphant defence of himself, and turned the tables and the laugh upon Ogle to universal admiration. But it was a very unprofitable controversy to the whigs. The debate continued again till near Midnight— I walked home.
2. VI:30. Saturday

Morning visit from Mr Clay; and also from Mr Dunbar of Abington, who brought me a Letter of introduction, from Mr Ibrahim Bartlett of Quincy, and was accompanied by Mr Hunnewell of Charlestown, and Mr Wade also from the County of Middlesex— They are all delegates from a Convention of Young men, who are to assemble next Monday at Baltimore, to repeat the nomination of William Henry Harrison, and John Tyler, as Candidates for the Offices of President and Vice-President of the United States at the Presidential Election next December; which was made at Harrisburg last December— This Convention is expected to consist of delegates by thousands— It proves how wide spread and how deeply rooted is the disaffection to the Administration of Martin Van Buren.— Mr Hunnewell told me that when I sailed from Charlestown in August 1809. in the ship Horace for St. Petersburg, he had been engaged as a Cabin boy in the same ship—that he lost the voyage by the change of the Captain; to his great disappointment. That he has followed the sea for many years since that time; but has now settled down in permanent residence at Charlestown— I was about half an hour belated at the house which I found in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Casey in the chair hard at work on the civil and diplomatic appropriation-Bill. The Committee of investigation upon the Swartwout and Price defalcations, had made two reports Majority and minority, both inculpating Enos T. Throop, Naval Officer at New-York but now Charge d’affaires at Naples Virgil Maxcy Solicitor of the Treasury, now Charge d’Affaires to Belgium, and Henry D. Gilpin Solicitor of the Treasury, now Attorney General all for neglect of duty in their several Offices, from which cause Swartwout’s delinquency was going on and increasing for a succession of years undetected Stanly had moved to strike out the appropriations for the salaries of these persons, and a long debate ensued upon the merits of the reports and of these Officers— As a set off for delinquencies Albert Smith charged that General Harrison had remained six Months at home after being appointed by me, Minister to the Republic of Columbia; and started off as soon as he had ascertained that Jackson was elected in my place— I noticed this mode of defending present, existing remediable delinquencies by adducing old false charges of delinquency as justification. M’Kay attempted to discredit the reports by insisting that the House had not acted upon them— I made a short reply to him— The reports were presented on the last day of the Session, and were not even printed till weeks after the Congress was extinct— The items were all retained; and after much further debate the Bill and amendments were reported to the house, passed to a 3d. reading 145 to 15. and passed. About 7. O’Clock the house suspended the rules and adjourned to 8. Monday Morning then to adjourn over till Thursday, to have the Carpets taken up and Hall put in its summer dress— Also for attendance at the Baltimore Convention and the races.
3. V:30 Sunday.

When I came home last Evening, I found Miss Cutts here, but she soon went away— I know not how to describe the effect upon my body and mind of such a week as I have just past—labouring day and night in legislative deliberation, upon a measure the final consummation of which was scarcely susceptible of divided opinion— War against an administration upon the petty details of an appropriation bill suits neither my taste nor my principles— I was ready to pass it as it went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Its worst feature was a pitiful attempt to filch about 100000 dollars from the sums indispensable for the completion of the public buildings, by defrauding the poor workmen upon them at daily wages, of their dues— This attempt I contributed to defeat, and the appropriations in the bill are sufficient to pay up all the arrearages, and to continue the works— They had actually suspended them, and left the workmen without employment— Several of them yesterday morning accosted me as I was walking to the Capitol, intreating me to use my influence with Mr Noland to set them to work again— I spoke to Petrikin, who told me both he and Governor Lincoln had advised Noland to set the men to work. I sent for Noland himself and intreated him to do so— He said he was willing, but Mr Keim, an administration member of the Committee on the public buildings had told him it was doubtful whether the appropriation would pass— I asked him to set the men to work on my responsibility, and he said he would— I had this morning another visit from the Chevalier Friedrichsthal, and an hour of conversation with him— He said he had been mistaken in telling me that the black and coloured population of the Island of St Domingo had diminished within the last forty years, but that it had not much increased, and that all its other sources of prosperity were constantly declining— He thinks that the natural abode of the African race is within 8 degrees North and South of the equator, and that the Negro is physically morally, and mentally inferior to the European and the Caucasian man. He departs upon his tour next Wednesday.— I attended the morning public worship at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Wood preach from Psalm 119.126. [“]It is time for thee, Lord, to work; for they have made void thy Law”— No signs of the Church’s filling up— But he gave notice of the distribution at the church doors of a tract in four pages which head recently fallen in his way, entitled more than fifty reasons for attendance at church on the Sabbath— After dinner at St. Johns Church the Revd. Mr Price read the Evening service for the second Sunday after Easter and preached from Luke 9.23. [“]And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself,—and take up his cross daily, and follow me.” The duty of submission to the afflictive dispensations of Providence enjoined in handsome composition and good delivery with some superfluous quotation of verses— J. Sergeant was there and walked home with me. Going to Baltimore to-morrow—and thence to Philadelphia.
4. V:30. Monday.

One of our horses has been very sick ever since last Friday, and I must do all my travelling again on foot— I walked this morning to the Capitol and at precisely 8 O’Clock found the Speaker already in the chair and the Clerk reading the Journal of Saturday. There were about twenty members present— They immediately adjourned. I went into the Law Library chamber, and there consulted several books to trace the doctrine of the English lawyers, that Nations are not bound to respect or protect each others revenue laws— I made extracts from Blackstone, Emerigon and the Term Reports, without being able to complete my enquiries— The first development of the doctrine is in the Statute of 19 George 2. c. 37. against wager policies—excepting vessels engaged in trade with Spain and Portugals dominions. Blackstone says that the reasons for this exception are sufficiently obvious, and betrays a consciousness of their dishonesty by suppressing what they were— Emerigon explains Blackstone’s meaning to be—smuggling— And Buller in the Term Reports says he had heard Lord Mansfield say it was to encourage the smuggling trade with the Spanish and Portuguese Colonies— Pothier insists with great force that the principle itself is wrong—which Emerigon admits, but justifies the French practice as a sort of reprizal upon that of the English and Spaniards— In the case of Amory vs Gilman— 2. Massachusetts Reports p. 1. the judges of the Supreme Court of that State incline to the opinion that at common Law, wager policies was not valid; and that the Statute of 19 George 2. c. 37. was never adopted in this Country. The result of all for which I collect these facts is to explain the principles upon which the Yorkshire clothiers, encouraged by Act of Parliament and King’s Bench judges, practice smuggling in foreign Countries— And this I wish to connect, would that I could with the trial of Wood’s case, at New-York, and the systematic smuggling of the importers of woollens, requiring, further Legislative provisions as well for the collection of the revenue as for the protection of our own manufactures— After spending four hours in this Law Library, I went to Mr Hassler’s establishment, where he is carrying on at once the mapping for the Coast Survey, and the fabrication of weights and measures for distribution to all the States and Custom houses of the Union— The weights and measures are all of brass, and a foundery is a part of the establishment— There are a number of astronomical instruments old and new for the survey of the coast and he has more than twenty men at work under him, engineers for the mapping and all Germans for the weights and measures. Hassler himself and his whole establishment would be admirable subjects for Hogarth or Cruikshank, and still better for a Daguerrotype fac-simile.—If I had a month of leisure I would look deeper into them—100000 dollars have been this year appropriated for Mr Hassler’s labours without a murmur. I walked home in the face of a hurricane which almost blinded me with showers of gravel dust— Too much wearied and exhausted for evening toil.
5. V:30. Tuesday.

The continual labour night and day last week, in the house of Representatives has so close an affinity to the dissipation of worldly life, that I have not recovered from it yet; for steady application to business— I called this morning on the Commissioner of Pensions, and left with him a Letter from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn L.I. enclosing two certificates in support of the claim of Phebe Reeve to a Pension— And thence I went to the Capitol, and there spent two hours in making extracts and reading cases on the question of the lawfulness of wager policies, and the encouragement of smuggling in foreign countries— A subject to which I cannot do justice— I made the extract from Pothier; whose censure upon the English doctrine of encouraging the trade of smugglers in foreign countries appears to be just— There is one principle indeed which may justify the illicit trade countenanced by Lord Mansfield and encouraged by the Act of Parliament of 19. George 2. ch. 37— The Spanish and Portuguese exclusive monopolies of their colony trade; by forbidding all intercourse of foreigners with them was a violation of natural right; and nature will vindicate her rights The Sovereign power of Spain and Portugal did not warrant their sanguinary laws of exclusion— Foreigners might be justified in evading them; nor could the Governments of those foreigners be blamed for countenancing and encouraging them in their evasion— This plea could not be urged by the Britis Government which excluded all foreign trade with their own Colonies; though not so ferociously as the Spaniards and Portuguese— Emerigon gives an extract from the Abbe Raynal, denouncing all these exclusive monopolies, and if Governments violate the Laws of natural justice, their subjects seem scarcely sensurable for evading them by fraud. I was obliged to hasten home to dinner, without closing my researches; and I had evening visits from Mr Joseph Pratt of Carver, who brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Jacob H Loud, and with whom came Mr Savery of New-York— Then Mr Richards of Quincy with Mr Hersey of Boston—followed by Mr Bates of Wareham, Mr Beal of Kingston and Mr Doane of Cohassett—all delegates from Massachusetts to the innumerable convention of Young men, held yesterday and this day at Baltimore to respond to the nomination last winter at Harrisburg of Harrison and Tyler, for election as President, and Vice President of the United States.— The Chevalier Friedrichsthal was also here.
6. V. Wednesday

The members of the Baltimore whig convention of young men, are flocking to this city by hundreds— The convention itself consisted of thousands; an immense unwieldy mass of political machinery to accomplish nothing—to form a procession polluted by a foul and unpunished murder of one of their own marshals, and by the loss of several other lives— I am assured that the number of delegates in attendance from the single State of Massachusetts was not less than 1200. and in the midst of this throng Henry Clay, Daniel Webster, William C. Preston Senators of the United States and four times the number of members of the House of Representatives, have been two days straining their lungs, and cracking their voices to fill this multitude of windy sound,—for the glorification of William Henry Harrison and the vituperation of Martin Van Buren— I found in the Globe of last Evening a notice—of a trial before judge Hopkinson at Philadelphia—upon a seizure of under invoiced woollens, upon which after 56. days of conflict in court, the jury were out not more than 11. minutes, and returned a verdict for the prosecution— As the report of this trial, might be of use in the discussion upon my revenue Bill— I called at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury and enquired if he had received any report of the case from the District Attorney or Collector at Philadelphia— The only information that he had of the case was a paragraph in a Philadelphia Newspaper which he gave me— But he asked the comptroller Barker to write to Philadelphia for a copy of Judge Hopkinson’s charge to the jury and a report of the trial. Mr Buchanan the Senator from Pennsylvania came in while I was there, no enquire concerning the renomination of some drunkard whom he patronizes and whose commission is to expire next July. I asked Mr Woodbury concerning the payment of Treasury Notes, and upon what terms they are now issued. He referred me to the first Auditor for payment, and said that he had now proposals to take Treasury Notes at 5 2/5 and also at 5 percent— I enquired if there was any thing new respecting the boundary by the Great Western recently arrived— He believed not— He mentioned that the Surveyor at Cincinnati had been sued and damages laid at 20,000 dollars for a seizure of imported goods owned in England I spoke of the Letter received from him respecting crude and refined Saltpetre; upon which I thought the Committee of Manufactures would not act— I went to the Capitol, and made extracts from Phillips on Evidence; and examined authorities on the disqualification of witnesses interested in the question of the suit— At Gadsby’s door I met great numbers of the delegates from the Baltimore Convention many of whom were introduced to me, by members of Congress— Others in the Library chamber. This afternoon I had a visit from Mr Crooks the Canadian claimant, and in the Evening from Mr Osborne, a member of the House of Representatives—with six of the Delegates from that State— There was also a numerous assemblage of the delegates this Evening, in front of the City hall, where they were addressed by sundry members of Congress and others.
7. V:30. Thursday

I attended this morning at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures but no other member of the Committee was there— Mr Southard brought there, and introduced to me several members from New-Jersey of the Baltimore whig Convention of young men— The City is flooded with them—and I was told that not less than six hundred of them came on in the cars yesterday morning— This was the day fixed for the consideration by the house of the revenue collection Bill N. 100 reported by the Committee of manufactures. John W. Jones, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means is gone home to Virginia. The acting chairman, Atherton came and asked me to allow the amendments of the Senate to the general appropriation Bill to be taken up—to which I consented— Cave Johnson, Chairman of the Committee of Military Affairs asked to be, and was excused on account of ill health— The House then went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, upon the Bill N. 100 John Bell of Tennessee in the Chair; the Bill was read through, and the Chairman directed that it should then be read by Sections— I sent to the Clerk’s table one of the fifty memorials from the manufacturers upon which the bill was founded, and after it was read the Clerk was proceeding to read the first Section of the Bill, when Rhett of South-Carolina started up, and moved to recommit the Bill— The Chairman asked him if he proposed any amendment to the first Section—he said his objection was to the whole bill—he was told that his motion to recommit was not in order, and he moved to strike out the enacting clause—and then made a speech of half or three quarters of an hour against various provisions of the Bill— The amendments of the Senate to the appropriation Bill having then come in, Atherton with my consent moved that the Committee should rise, which they did— The House then took up the amendments of the Senate to the general appropriation Bill, one of which was to strike out the item of 45000 dollars for the second and third Volumes of Clarke and Force’s Documentary History of the United States; in which amendment the house after some debate concurred by yeas and nays 73 to 48 a close party vote— The house then at my motion made the Bill N. 100 the special order of the day for to-morrow and adjourned about 5 O’Clock— I had visits after dinner from Mr Crane of Richmond Virginia, a young man recently married to my niece Mrs Treadway’s daughter Susan Clark. He brought me a Letter of introduction from Mrs Treadway and is returning from the whig convention of young men at Baltimore, to which he went as a delegate. Visits also from Coll. Totten, and Mr A. D. Bache President of the Girard College, who is here attending a National Convention on the subject of Education.— I attended at the House of Mr Poinsett The Secretary of War a Meeting of Scientific men, on the proposal to form a Cabinet and a Society of Natural history—15 present mostly foreigners. But T. H. Benton, and George M Keim were there, and accordingly nothing was done— I had an invitation to the Russian Minister Bodisco’s Ball but was disappointed, and did not go.
8. VI:30. Friday.

Mr Trist, Consul of the United States at the Havana was here this morning, and I had a long conversation with him, upon the charges against his official conduct which are now under consideration by the Committee of Commerce of the House of Representatives— The charges are of two kinds—first by several masters of vessels complain of abusive official ill treatment of them—and secondly of his gross and culpable connivance at the African Slave trade carried on from the United States, chiefly from Baltimore through the Havana— I had received two Letters from him urging me to bring the matter forward in the House of Representatives; and I assigned now to him my reasons for declining to do this— The chief of which was that under his solemn protestations of innocence, and his undoubting confidence of proving it— I was not willing to place myself before the House and the Country in the attitude of his accuser— He said it was his perfect confidence in the success of his defence that had made him desire that the investigation should be undertaken by me.— He has just now returned from Baltimore where he has been as a witness upon two trials for Slave-trade cases: in both of which the defendants were acquitted—both, he says undoubtedly guilty. I suppose it as impossible to convict a Slave trader at Baltimore as in the Island of Cuba, and I fear Mr Trist’s defence rests on the same basis as that of the late defendants at Baltimore; the inexecutability of the Law. He told me that no man’s life would be safe who should attempt to execute the Law at the Havana— Immediately on the meeting of the House, they went at my motion into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Bell of Tennessee in the Chair, upon my revenue Bill N. 100— The day was spent in debating it.— Rhett followed up his assault of yesterday with more pertinacity than success— After some discussion, he withdrew his motion to strike out the enacting clause, and moved that the Committee to rise and report the Bill, with the view to move the recommitment of the Bill to the Committee of Manufactures— Upon this motion he made a second Speech of half an hour—opposed by Tillinghast, Sergeant, and myself and the motion was rejected by a majority of more than three to one— The bill was then taken up by Sections as it should have been at first— Rhett moved to strike out the 6th. Section, but after full discussion this motion was also rejected.— The debate was continued to the 8th. Section, sundry amendments proposed by Tillinghast and Everett being adopted as they proceeded— Curtis moved to strike out part of the 8th. Section whereupon the debate was protracted till past five when at Habersham’s motion the Committee rose without a quorum— I moved that the Bill should be made the special order of the day again for to-morrow, but there was no quorum to vote— The races had taken off upwards of one hundred members, and I had been obliged to move a call of the house to get a quorum vote upon one of the incidental questions raised by Mr Rhett— Adjourned at half past 5. Rain almost all day. I rode home, and wasted great part of the Evening in slumber and in writing verses on the wants of man—
9. V:30. Saturday

The weather is so cold and raw, with much rain that we have been obliged to rekindle the fires in the dining room and in my own chamber— I finished last Night almost sleepless and this morning my verses upon the wants of man.— I suppose it is my intense anxiety for the Bill now under my charge which bereaves me of sleep, and the composition of verses, trifling upon another is the only mode of relieving myself from the continual pressure upon the brain of thought upon one subject, through a sleepless Night— I partly rode this morning to the Capitol with my Granddaughter Mary Louisa who was going to School, and in the house immediately after the reading of the Journal they went at my motion into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, upon the Revenue Bill N. 100. Bell of Tennessee in the Chair— The question pending at the adjournment yesterday, was upon Curtis’s motion to strike out a clause in the 8th. Section relieving the United States from the payment of costs on the appointment of a Commissioner on their part to attend at the taking of a deposition abroad at the instance of the defendant in a suit instituted by the United States for a forfeiture or a fraudulent entry— The motion to strike out was rejected in the Committee— But the Section the most hotly contested as yet, and perhaps of the whole bill, was the 9th. which I had already proposed to amend, very considerably restricting it compared with the Section proposed by the Collector and district Attorney at New-York— The Section disables the testimony of persons having the same interest with the party to the suit, though not interested in the event of the suit itself— Rhett was ferocious for striking out first the amended and then the original Section—but the question to strike out the original, and insert the amended Section was carried by a considerable majority, and then the motion to strike out the amended Section was debated for the remainder of the day— The three members from the City of New-York, James Monroe, Curtis and Hoffman, D. D. Barnard, Governor Lincoln, Sergeant, and Underwood, came out in legion strength against it, and Tillinghast, a member of the Committee of Manufactures gave it up and turned against it— Briggs and Vanderpoel sustained me with good service— M’Kay of North-Carolina promised me that he would but did not—the question upon striking out was taken by tellers 48 to 66.—no quorum. I had already been obliged to move a call of the house to obtain a quorum on a preceding question It was now near six O’Clock— The Committee rose and the House adjourned.— There was a meeting of the Convention upon Education in the Hall this evening which I could not attend—but I met Mr and Mrs Dickinson at a party at Mr B. O. Tayloe’s.
10. VI:30 Sunday

Mr Stansbury gave me last evening seventy pages of his report, of the debate of the preceding day with a request that I would revise my part of it to have it in readiness for the printer this morning. 45 pages. This was impossible— Mr Gales came this morning to enquire if the manuscript was ready. It would have been, but for the extracts from books and vouchers which I read and, my comment upon which constituted nine tenths of my speech. There can be no adequate conception without them and some of the very books from which I read the extracts are locked up in the Law Library at the Capitol. Mr Gales said it would of course be impossible to print that part of the debate in the Intelligencer to-morrow. I told him I had not yet received for revisal Wheeler’s part of my speech on the resolution for abolishing the Committee on the public expenditures— He said that must be preceded by Ogle’s speech on the general appropriation Bill— I observed that he had not yet published my report on the Smithsonian bequest— He said the difficulty was that it would occupy from twelve to fourteen columns of the paper; but it should be published as soon as possible— I walked to the Capitol, and heard the Revd. Robert Newton a celebrated and eloquent preacher of the British Wesleyan Methodists, very recently arrived from England, and representing that denomination, as their delegate from the British Conference— He preached from Philippians 3.8. [“]Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus, my Lord:”— The excellency of the knowledge of Christianity, and the sacrifices of all other things to obtain it, formed a copious theme for the discourse— It was eloquent, argumentative, logical, persuasive, but in a thoroughly beaten and somewhat hacknied path; dealing largely in generalities, and more ethical than pathetic.— In comparison with Mr Cookman— Mr Newton’s range of power is perhaps more comprehensive but less energetic.— I spoke after the Sermon with Dr Sewall, who introduced Mr Newton to me; and with Mr William L. Storrs a member of the house from Connecticut, who had yesterday given me a Letter, to read from R. S. Baldwin, the leading Counsel of the Africans of the Amistad— I cannot suppress, and yet must controul. There is a scandalous mistranslation of one of the Spanish papers, in the Document N. 185. noticed by Mr Baldwin, and concerning which I received this day a Letter from Lewis Tappan of New-York— Mary E. E. Cutts was here this afternoon and went with me to St. John’s Church, where Mr Boyd read the Evening service for the third Sunday after Easter, and preached from Acts 18.17. “And Gallio cared for none of those things.” Mr Boyd’s Discourse was upon the sin of indifference to religion. It is not advantageous to Mr Boyd to be heard on the same day, after such an Orator as Mr Newton. Mr Boyd announced the 11th. Psalm taken from the 14th. Psalm of David— I observed a difference in his reading from that of the prayer book which I had before me, in the last verse of the Psalm. Sergeant was there and after Church told me of a great whig gain, at a recent election, of a member to the Pennsylvania Legislature in the place of M’Elwee recently expelled— I walked home with Miss Cutts— Brought up this diary, writing by Lamp-light—
11. V:30. Monday

Crabbe of Alabama moved that from and after this day, the house should meet at 11. A.M till further order—objection was made—he moved a suspension of the rules which was carried—120 to 23. Henry offered an amendment that the house would take a recess from 1/2 past 2 to 4 O’Clock— And Dawson offered a joint Resolution that Congress will adjourn on the 15th. of June—both these propositions were cut off by the previous question— The Resolution was adopted without opposition— This was regularly the bi-weekly petition day. But on my enquiring of the Speaker he said there was a special order for the Report on the printing—whereupon I moved the House to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the Revenue Bill N. 100. There were at least 20 members up with resolutions and petitions which they wished to present, but my motion prevailed, and the Speaker gave the Chair to Mr Bell. The question was taken by Tellers upon Rhett’s motion to strike out the 9th Section of the Bill as amended, and the motion was rejected 62 to 83.— In the 10th. Section, Rhett moved to strike out the disqualification for holding an Office annexed as a penalty for any custom-house Officer, aiding and abetting any fraud on the revenue. He denied the right of Congress to add to the disqualifications declared by the Constitution. Others concurred with him; but after a stubborn debate the motion was rejected 48 to 82. Cushing moved an additional section making it penal for any subordinate Custom-house Officer to receive presents for the performance of his duty, which after some discussion was adopted with my consent— The remaining Sections of the Bill and Amendments were then successively read through, without much opposition till past 6. O’Clock when I moved the Committee to rise and report the Bill and amendments.— Holmes of Charleston, South-Carolina then rose and said that exhausted as the Committee and he himself then were, he should not then make a speech; but he would not object to the Bill’s being reported to the house with the understanding that the previous question should not be started to deprive him of the opportunity of shewing that this was the most pernicious Bill, and the most subversive of the rights of the People that was ever presented to the consideration of the American Congress. I said I hoped no person would move the previous question, till the gentleman should have had full range to his heart’s content to expose before the house and the world, all the horrors of the Bill—upon which there was a shout of laughter and the Bill was reported to the house, and ordered to be printed— The House then adjourned— I had an evening visit from Mr Maxwell and Mr Yorke, two of the excluded members from New-Jersey with a Mr Van Dyke, also from that State. All the rest of the Evening I was occupied in reading part of the long opinion of Judge Hopkinson, in the recent trial at Philadelphia, on the case of John Taylor junr. and William Blackburne and Co.
12. V. Tuesday.

Morning visit from Mr Saltonstall, with one of his constituents from Lynn and a young clergyman from Sharon I was at my Seat in the House at 11. O’Clock. But a call of the house, moved by Governor Lincoln was necessary to procure a Quorum. Edward Davies of Pennsylvania moved to suspend the rules for a Resolution to take a recess from half past 2 to 4 O’Clock—but the motion failed for lack of two thirds 81. to 60.— A Message from the President with documents relating to the delivery of persons charged with crimes were referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs, and also the Message and Documents relating to the Negroes of l’amistad. I moved that 5000 extra-copies of the Message this day received should be printed— Vote 83 to 35—no Quorum—then by yeas and nays 87 to 67. not two thirds—lost— I moved the reference to the Committee on the Judiciary.— Dromgoole to the Committee of foreign Affairs—which prevailed— Several Executive communications were disposed of. Jenifer obtained an order to have 5000 extra-copies printed of the Memorial and proceedings of the Convention of Tobacco planters— And Campbell Chairman of the Committee of Elections, obtained leave for the Committee to have printed such papers before them concerning the contested elections, as they shall think proper— Graham asked leave to present a petition to which I objected unless all other members should be allowed to present theirs. The special order of the day was the report on the printing, for which Black, the Chairman of the Committee said he was ready. It was postponed till to-morrow— The Bill to ensure the more faithful execution of the laws relating to the collection of duties on imports—as reported with amendments yesterday from the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—was now taken up by general consent— Evans from the Committee of Ways and Means offered an amendment that the mark Banco should be valued at the Custom house at 35 1/2 cents, to which I object as a tack. The Amendments reported by the Committee of the whole were all adopted by one vote—excepting the 9th. Section— Holmes made a speech of nearly two hours against the whole Bill, immediately after which the previous question was moved and seconded. The Speaker said the main question was upon the engrossment of the Bill; but at my request a separate vote was taken by yeas and nays upon the motion to strike out the 9th Section, which motion failed 72 to 85— The vote for the engrossment of the Bill was 122 to 30. and it was immediately read the third time by its title and passed without a decision— The house immediately, about half past 2 adjourned, for the members to go and examine and invention to prevent the explosion of Steamboat boilers: I went into the Senate chamber mentioned the passage of my bill to Mr Webster and requested his particular attention to it, which he promised— No gratitude can equal my obligation for the reward of all the preparatory labour and study that I have given for the discussion of this Bill; nor could there be a more impressive admonition to me, faithfully to persist in the same practice.— Evening visit from Joseph John Gurney, with three other Quaker Friends— He gave me an account of his recent visit to sundry West-India-Islands.
13. V. Wednesday

Mr Saltonstall, who lodges only two doors from our house, was robbed last in his bed chamber while asleep— Mr Reed was robbed two or three weeks since at his lodgings in the same way. I called this morning at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, and informed him of the passage of the revenue Bill, and of the vehement and pertinacious opposition which it encountered in the house— I said it was now before the Senate, and would need there the support of the friends of the administration— And I would suggest to him the expediency of conferring with the Chairman of the Senate’s Committee of finance upon it. I told him I had not yet had the opportunity of laying before the Committee of Manufactures his communications respecting crude and refined Saltpetre, and I warned him of the discontents roused by the recent new constructions of the Tariff Laws, on this and other subjects— I have received several Letters upon this subject of crude and refined Saltpetre, and one from P. P. F. Degrand at Boston— At the House Henry presented a Memorial from Beaver County Pennsylvania, for a revision of the Tariff and the protection of the manufactures referred to our Committee— The special order of the day was upon the two reports from the Committee on the public printing; a mere party conflict which was debated the whole day between Black a pepper hot Georgian, mover and Chairman of the Committee and Evans and Rice Garland the members of the minority— Between 3 and 5 O’Clock nearly two hours were consumed in alternate motions to adjourn and for a call of the house, both rejected by yeas and nays, till a call was at last ordered and a Quorum appeared— The question is between a reduction of 15 or of 25 per cent upon the present prices of the public printing— After 7. O’Clock, the previous question was moved—a Call of the house was ordered and 173 members answered. Motion to suspend further proceedings in the call, pending which a motion to adjourn succeeded and after 8 I reached home— William Smith Cruft of New-York, called me out at the house; being here as he said on a visit of curiosity— I went into the Senate chamber and found them idly debating a Bankrupt Law— While I was there, the Revenue collection Bill from the House was referred to the Committee of Finance. I gave a copy of the Bill to Mr John Davis, and promised to send the papers to Mr Webster— A remonstrance against the Bill signed by 73 commercial houses in New-York was this day received too late to be presented to the House, but which will come before the Senate— I made some arrangement of the papers to send them to Mr Webster; but was not able to revise Stansbury’s Notes of my speech last Friday and to prepare the extracts from the Books which I then read— Mr Cushing furnished me several additional papers to illustrate the expediency of the Bill, particularly Newspaper Reports of the trial of the Bottomly case at Boston—
14. V: Thursday

Mr Cruft called on me this morning, and I returned to him a Volume which he had sent me last Evening published in England by A. Trotter upon the debts of our separate States— Mr Cruft proposes to leave the City to-morrow— This was the day of Meeting for the Committee of Manufactures; but no Quorum attended— Present Adams, Mitchell, Davis, Tillinghast— Absent, Dromgoole, Nisbett, Eastman, Slade, Worthington. There was a Bill from the Senate for admitting duty-free, paintings and sculpture by American Artists in Europe—and also the communications from the Secretary of the Treasury respecting crude and refined Saltpetre, the consideration of which must of course be postponed till next Thursday. In the house Crabb of Alabama asked to be excused and was excused from further service on the Committee of Elections, alledging feeble health and too hard work— Crabb is an Alabama whig Slaveholder; and his real motive is to slink from the responsibility of reporting upon the contested elections. Flinch at a pinch is his motto— The adjournment last Night was upon a call of the house at a motion for the previous question upon an amendment moved by Petrikin to the Resolutions offered by the minority of the Committee on the printing, as a substitute for the Resolutions reported by Black, Chairman of that Committee, from the majority— The call of last Night was considered as still pending this morning, but the Speaker said if now pursued, no others than those absent last Evening would now be called— So proceedings on the call of last evening were superseded and Morgan moved a new call— But the special order of this day was the report of the select committee on the fray between Bynum and Rice Garland, and it consumed the day— The Committee had reported only the facts and testimony— But Underwood the chairman a worthy amiable man, full of speculative fancies, of fluent tongue, a little self-conceit or as the french say abounding in his own sense, and a weak judgment offered a string of crude undigested resolutions, for defining the privileges of the house and its members, and a code for the punishment of contempts— Holmes of Charleston S.C. with a superfluity of energy more than enough to make up for Underwood’s want of it moved that Rice Garland and Jesse A. Bynum should both be expelled for fighting on the floor of the House— Briggs moved a Resolution declaring that Bynum and Garland had violated the privileges of the house, and on this motion the previous question was ordered— I had purposely remained silent till then—but I could stand it no longer. I said I could not vote them guilty of a breach of privilege, without first hearing them— Whereupon the previous question was reconsidered a new debate was started, and finally the report of the select Committee was recommitted with instructions to the Committee to report to the House what to do, both in the present case and to avoid such disorders in future. Three or four motions were made to lay the whole subject on the table for all which I voted, and to that complexion it must come at last— The duelling bill is the best preservative from fatal disorders that has yet been devised; and as to petty fisti-cuffs they will occasionally occur, and only disgrace one or both parties to them— Adjourned about 6. O’Clock.
15. IV:30. Friday

General Miller, au Service du Perou on his card, I know nothing more of him, paid me a morning visit— He is a handsome, Grenadier looking man, lately from Peru, by the way of Mexico, and gave me some particulars of the present condition of these South American Republics, but said nothing of his own purpose in coming to this Country— Of all the Southern Republics, he thinks that Chili has the best Government and has made the greatest progress in the advancement of political Science—but Chili has just issued victorious from a War with Peru, and now gives the Law to that Republic: General Miller’s visit belated me at the house, where I found them taking the yeas and nays on a motion to suspend the rules for a Resolution to fix the first and second days of June to consider the business relating to the District of Columbia— Lost. 73 to 81. not even a majority. Then came the counter report on the public printing—on this the previous question had last evening been called by not ordered— Petrikin now withdrew his ten per cent amendment— The question was then taken by yeas and nays, on Evans’s minority report amendment—a reduction of 25 per cent on the present prices: lost by a vote of 98 to 107. a party vote shewing 205 members present; of whom four fifths of the time there are not 122 members in the house— At last the question came upon Black’s blundering Resolution to reduce the printing for Congress 15 per Cent—which passed 175 to 13. already 17 votes less than on the preceding question— The two reports on the separation of the public printing from the political press, were after some discussion laid on the table 104 to 89— Jones, Chairman of the Ways and Means, moved then a suspension of the rules, to go in to Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the Independent Treasury-Bill—lost. 117 to 83. not two thirds— As Jones well knew, when he made the motion, that the event would be.— The house took up private business. I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures to arrange the papers concerning the revenue collection-bill, to be sent to Mr. Webster, for the Senate’s Committee of Finance, and after an hour and a half spent there returned, and found the house, voting on the engrossment of the New-York fire bill—but on the previous question they refused to take the main question, on the passage of the bill now: that is, this day— Then followed another private Bill, reported by Mr Lawrence, now absent, and now lost by the chicanery of Petrikin, and the Planter-malice of Rhett.— There was no Quorum and after an hour of feeble struggling to get one, the house adjourned about 5— At 8 this Evening I attended at the house, of Mr Poinsett, Secretary of War, the second meeting for the purpose of forming a National Institution for the promotion of Science, which was done. A Constitution was reported—read, discussed adopted and signed—for a Society— There were 25 persons present—among whom Govr Lincoln, Mr Cushing, Mr Tillinghast, Benjamin Tappan, Senator from Ohio, Charles J. Ingersoll, Genl. Macomb, R. Greenhow &c— It was midnight when I came home.—
16. VI. Saturday.

Elizabeth Pierce was here this morning, and said her Sister Mrs Telfair was very dangerously ill with the Dysentery; and asked me to recommend a physician to whom she might apply in behalf of her poor Sister— I advised her to apply to Dr Thomas— She enquired also what prospect there was of the house’s passing the bill in their favour this day— I gave her no encouragement to hope for this day—but was ashamed to tell here there was no prospect of their obtaining any thing at the present Session of Congress. I reached the Capitol about half past ten, but was engaged in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures arranging the papers for the Senate’s Committee of finance on the revenue Bill, about an hour— I found the House taking the yeas and nays, on a motion to suspend the rules for a resolution, from and after the next Monday to take a daily recess from half past 2 to 4 P.M— The rules were suspended and the Resolution adopted by the previous question and acclamation, drowning an amendment proposed by D. D. Barnard, that the house for the remainder of the Session should meet at 10. A.M—and adjourn at 4. P.M. holding but one Session each day— There was a Letter read from Blair and Rives, stating that for certain parts of the public printing, not specified in the Resolution adopted yesterday, they should continue to charge as they have done heretofore— Briggs moved to reconsider the Resolution adopted yesterday with a view to propose a reduction of 20 per Cent on the present prices—rejectedtoThat Bill for amending the New-York fire Bill, was lost at the third readingtoby the careless neglect of Curtis, chairman of the Committee of Commerce who reported it; in not being ready to meet captious objections— Proffit voted against the Bill, giving notice that he should move a reconsideration— Griffin a stolid South Carolinian, took the start of Proffit, and instantly after the rejection of the Bill moved a reconsideration and the Previous Question— The reconsideration was thus rejectedto—and all this sharping passes without rebuke and without shame— The same fate attended the Bill reported by Mr Lawrence, from the Committee of Ways and Means, insidiously assailed by Rhett of that Committee in aid of Petrikin, and not another member of the Committee acquainted with the merits of the case, to defend— The Speaker called upon the Committees for Reports—and having none to make, I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and finished the arrangement of the papers concerning the revenue Bill for the Senate’s Committee of Finance; which I took to the Clerks Office and directed them to be sent to Mr Webster— On returning to the house between 3 and 4 I found them taking the yeas and nays, on a question to adjourn which was carried. They had been in Committee of the whole Briggs in the Chair— I went again to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and spent two hours in making extracts to be printed with my Speech on the Revenue Bill— Past six when I reached home— Midsummer weather [symbols]
17. V:30 Sunday.

Walk to the Capitol, and heard Joseph John Gurney’s display of Quaker eloquence He took for his text without naming the book Matthew 22.42— [“]What think ye of Christ? whose Son is he? They say unto him, The son of David. 43. He saith unto them, How then doth David in spirit call him Lord, saying, 44. The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, till I make thine enemies thy foot-stool? 45. If David then call him Lord, how is he his son? 46. And no man was able to answer him a word; neither durst any man, from that day forth, ask him any more questions.” The discourse somewhat desultory, was on the perfect union of the divine and human nature in the person of Christ—a hacknied and incomprehensible theme— Friend Gurney has the faculty of commanding attention; the first of all qualifications for an Orator; and with which he may dispense with all others— His face is immovable as a marble Statue— He speaks with one unvaried tone of voice, and slow, clear, distinct articulation.— He has an unpleasant quaker drawl, and very inelegant pronunciation of many words—turning the vowel o into a broad u—such as glurrious for glorious— He is grave—earnest—evidently sincere—good hearted kind, and thinks himself not a whit behind the chiefest of the Apostles.— His argument was not strong but he evidently believed what he said— The members seats were full, chiefly of women—but very few in the galleries— He twice requested the audience to hold the meeting after the manner of the Society of Friends for a few minutes in solemn silence, which was done— When he resumed speaking he said he hoped the interval had been employed by every individual present in fervent prayer. Jenifer was there and gave me the list of flowers composing the bouquet which he says he has received from a young lady 200 miles distant, explained by Flora’s dictionary, and which he yesterday challenged me to answer. Jenifer is a sprightly, horse racing man of gallantry and fashion—politically a high-spirited duelist whig, and zealous champion of the tobacco-planting interest; and morally a gay Lothario, affecting conquests of fair Ladies hearts, and vain of this posy from a child. I wrote the verses, which may perhaps do for his Lady’s Album, not fit to be seen any where else— After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Boyd read the Service for the 4th. Sunday after Easter, and Mr Higbee preached from 1. John 4.8. “God is love”— This Gentleman once minister of the Episcopal Trinity Church in this City, and chaplain to the Senate, now settled at the Trinity Church in New-York is renowned among the preachers of the land, but his style is too merely declamatory for my taste— I never relished him much, and was not more reconciled to his manner, by his commonplace appeals to the pathetics of the crucifixion— The day was intensely warm— Miss Cutts here after Church—
18. V:30. Monday

Mr Shea is an Englishman settled, and for the last twenty years resident at Baltimore— He has published a small book upon book-keeping by double entry; worth about half a dollar and which he generously charges only two and a half— I declined taking one, but he was not the less good humoured, and was disposed to launch into politics as a warm Harrison partizan; another sort of book keeping by double entry. Dr Thomas was here this morning to visit my wife, who is in very infirm health— I walked to the Capitol, purchasing at Darius Clagetts an Umbrella by the way— At the House it was the day for offering Resolutions but Atherton of the Committee of Ways and Means, Jones the Chairman being absent, moved a suspension of the rules to take up the Independent Treasury Bill— Call of the house—half an hour. Then suspended— Yeas and nays on the motion to suspend the rules 106 to 77—not two thirds—another half hour— Then Atherton moved again a suspension of the rules for a resolution to go into Committee of the whole on the independent Treasury Bill to morrow, and every following day till finished, yeas and nays 105 to 79. a third half hour— James Monroe then moved to suspend the rules to take up the general appropriation bills to morrow and following days, except Fridays and Saturdays till finished— I moved to lay the motion on the table and he withdrew it. Petrikin then moved to suspend the rules, and to receive petitions, which was carried—and the day was devoted to the reception of Petitions— The Speaker began with Massachusetts where he had left off on the last petition day, and I presented all that I had which was only 7. The only important one from Amasa Walker, and several hundred others for aid to complete a line of Railway from Boston to the Mississippi river, which was referred to the Committee of Roads and Canals. After this while the State of New-Jersey was called, I went into the Senate chamber, and found Mr Webster discoursing upon the conflicting projects for a bankrupt Law now under the consideration of that body, and neither of which will pass— Mr Silas Wright chairman of the Committee of finance, took me into the Committee room, where I had a long conversation with him on the revenue-bill— He had received the papers which I had prepared, but had scarcely looked into them— I explained to him the purport of them, and he promised to give them a thorough examination— He intimated that the fate of the Bill would depend upon the vote of Mr Webster, and that he was not friendly to the Bill— From half past 2 till 4. the house took a recess, during which and most of the afternoon sitting I was in the Committee room of the Committee of Manufactures arranging the extracts to be printed with my speech— Between 6. and 7 returning to the Hall, I found the house had adjourned, and walking over the floor was tripp’d up by the new laid matting, pitched forward, prostrated and dislocated my right shoulder.— Several of the members who remained in the house came immediately to my assistance, and attempted to set the bone with out success— I was taken to Mr. Monroe’s lodgings where in about half an hour the bone was set by Drs. Thomas and May junr— Evening at home—
19. V. Tuesday

I had rather an uneasy night and my right arm all this day in a sling— I write, against the kindest remonstrances of my family, and attended the morning sitting of the House against those of both my doctors— Several morning visitors called in— Weather at Summer heat. I rode to the Capitol, and stopped on my way at the office of the National Intelligencer and enquired of Mr Gales who came out to the Carriage for Wheeler’s Notes of my Speech of Saturday the 9th. instt. on the revenue Bill. He said he would procure them as soon as possible; and that he should begin the publication of the Smithsonian report to morrow. I found Mr Cushing speaking in the House upon the Bill for carrying into execution the Convention with Mexico; which he had brought up by obtaining a suspension of the rules— The Bill was discussed in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; James Garland in the chair— The only amendment of the Bill in Committee was the reduction of a Commissioners Salary from 3500 to 3000 dollars a year— The Bill was thus reported to the house passed for engrossment, and passed. I intended to have spoken upon this Bill; but my accident of yesterday disabled me, and it is better for me that it is so— Tillinghast moved a suspension of the Rules for a verbose resolution with a preamble to take up the general appropriation Bills successively, excluding the sub-treasury— Petrikin said he should move an amendment to include another Bill— Cost Johnson moved to lay Tillinghast’s motion on the table, and he withdrew it— Atherton moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the Union, to go through the first bill they should take up—yeas and nays 116 to 85. not two-thirds—and the strength of the sub-treasury Bill— At last came the proper order of the day— Bell’s bill for securing the freedom of elections. Gentry of Tennessee began a speech which he has had in keeping about six weeks— I went to the door of the Senate chamber where I met Asbury Dickins their Secretary— At my request he called out Mr Silas Wright with whom I had a further Conversation in his Committee room. I gave him two additional Letters from the Secretary of the Treasury which were among the papers connected with the revenue Bill—and I borrowed the unsigned paper from Mr Strobel the Consul at Bordeaux, which had been furnished me by Mr Burch— I borrowed also a Clerk to copy this paper for me and also an extract from Evans’s Appendix to his translation of Pothier which completes the preparation for the publication of my Speech of Friday the 8th instt. on the revenue Bill— The House at half past two took a recess and I rode home I did not return after dinner to the house, but repaired the lost of sleep last night by resorting to my bed for about two hours before Sunset— My appearance in the house this morning had occasioned some surprize—
20. V. Wednesday.

I had a night of quiet repose, but the soreness and pain in my shoulder was more troublesome this day than yesterday— This was a day of constant rain, and although convinced that I should have suffered less by attending at the House upon my duty than by staying at home, I yielded to the intreaties of my wife, and confined myself at home. Dr Thomas called this morning. I had time to ruminate upon my accident, and could scarcely refrain from repining at the peculiar untowardness of the disability just at this moment of my right arm— One of the first questions asked me by Dr May was whether the shoulder had ever been dislocated before. I had no recollection of any such event; but remembered having been told by my mother, that when a child two or three years old, I was straying out into the street, when the Nursery maid ran out after me, and seizing me by the right hand, gave it an involuntary sudden jerk, and dislocated the shoulder— My right hand has, consequently I suppose upon this early disability, been weaker than the left all my days— Always unable to write fast, and for the last twenty-five years unable to write at all as other men do with the forefinger and the thumb— My right hand has been many times further disabled by casualties of various and different kinds; against all which I have struggled to the utmost of my ability, considering it as the business and duty of my life to write; and receiving as admonitions and chastisements of Providence these occasional disabilities— With yesterday’s mail I received two copies of a Sermon on the present crisis in the Missionary operations of the American board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions, by Rufus Anderson D.D. one of the Secretaries of the board— It does not appear where or when the Sermon was delivered; but the publication is dated Boston 25. Feby. 1840. and in the same packet with the Sermons was a certificate that John Quincy Adams by a donation from Hon Samuel T. Armstrong is constituted an honorary member of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions—dated Boston Masstts. May 13. 1840. and signed Henry Hill Treasurer— But without any Letter from Mr Armstrong, or any intimation from him of his motive for constituting me, without consulting me, by a donation, an honorary member of this board— I read the Sermon, which is a most earnest call for more liberal contributions; stating a great falling off recently of liberality and zeal, and stating the average annual receipts of the last 3 years from 900 out of 1200 Massachusetts Congregational Churches to be 244000 dollars— I have always entertained doubts whether the usefulness of this well intended institution is at all adequate to its cost— Walter Hellen spent this Evening with us; and Mr Barnard called on me this Evening.— He told me that in the House—Bell’s Bill, to secure the freedom of Election had been rejected by a Call for the Previous Question— Then a Question if a pre-emption Bill from the Senate must go to a Committee of the whole—undecided— And the Sub-treasury, or Independent Treasury Bill taken up, on which C. Cushing had taken the floor.
21. V. Thursday.

The day of meeting for the Committee of Manufactures, but I was disabled from attending it in Season and there was no attendance of a Quorum.— After a more restless night than the preceding, I found my inability to write this day rather increased— Morning visits from John Connell Samuel Lawrence, L. Saltonstall, the Revd. W. M’Cormick and Joshua Dodge; besides Elizabeth Pierce, who came with a fresh precatory, minatory, monitory Letter from her Sister Mrs Telfair. I went to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions, and left with him Letters from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn L.I. relating to the Pensions of Francis Conklin, and of Major William Popham— Returning to my house I met there Mr Dodge and took him with me to the Capitol— At the House the Speaker had decided last Evening that the pre-emption Bill from the Senate must go into Committee of the whole, from which there had been an appeal— He had since then, last Evening examined the Journals of the house and had found one case in the year 1834. of a pre-emption Bill which had passed through the house without going into Committee of the whole—conforming therefore to the precedent, although his own opinion had not changed he reversed his decision of last Evening, and now decided that the Bill might pass to be engrossed without needing to go into Committee of the whole—from this decision Governor Lincoln appealed, but the Speaker was sustained by a vote of 100 to 91. The morning hour was gone— The orders of the day were called; a short bill from the Senate was passed— The house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Linn Banks in the Chair— Cushing commenced his formidable speech against the independent Treasury and continued until the recess without approaching to a close.— Mr Saltonstall rode home with me, and I took up Mary-Louisa on the way— I gathered all the papers for my Speech of Friday the 8th. and gave them at the National Intelligencer Office to Mr Gales. He promised its publication in the paper of the day after to-morrow, and that I should have the proof slips by to-morrow afternoon at 6 O’Clock— I met Mr. Alexander Vattemare in the lobby of the house and Mr Burch introduced him to me— I received a singular Letter from Charles A. Davis at New-York respecting the Portrait of Columbus in the Library— Enquired without success of Burch for the Letter from G. G. Barrell presenting it to Congress— After dinner I had a friendly visit from Mr Poinsett the Secretary of War— I did not return to the House— Mr Cushing there continued without concluding his Speech— Evening visit from Mr Hawley—and Mrs Thornton and Mrs Talbot with her daughter Mary spent the Evening with us.
22. V. Friday.

Mr Alexander Vattemare paid me a morning visit and shewed me printed copies of his two Memorials to the Legislative chambers of France— Told of the compliments he had received from the Emperor of Russia and the Prince royal of Prussia and other great men—bedaubed me with flattery till I sickened, and gave me to read a Letter from John C Spencer at Albany, as fulsome as his own conversation— John C. paid him in his own coin— He has a collection of curiosities on their way to Washington, which I am to see when they arrive— His time is precious— He has devoted his time and Fortune to this great undertaking of effecting mutual exchanges of duplicate books, and other rarities throughout the civilized world, and is very anxious to obtain a speedy decision upon his memorial to Congress.— Mr Trist called likewise upon me; and left with me certain despatches from him as Consul at the Havana to the Secretary of State, in justification of his official conduct now under investigation by the Committee of Commerce— I attended the morning Session of the House. Atherton moved a suspension of the rules to set aside the private business and fasten upon the sub-treasury-bill till it shall be gone through—lost by yeas and nays 86. to 88 after an ineffectual motion for a call of the House— The House went into Committee of the whole upon private Bills, Briggs in the Chair. Petrikin who has established himself as a sort of opponent general to all private claims had in one of his Speeches last evening been called to order by the chairman for reproachful reflections upon the house— The decision of the Chairman was now reversed—and Dr Petrikin proceeded without further interruption— He made and withdrew objections to sundry Bills; but a considerable number went through, and were reported with and without amendments, and others were laid over under the 26th. rule, confining the first and fourth Friday of each month to the consideration of private Bills against which there is no objection— At half past 2. the house took a recess— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, where Mr Gales came out and informed me that they were setting the types of my Speech of the 8th. for to-morrow’s paper and he promised to send me the proof slips—at four this afternoon which he did— It takes upwards of 4 columns— And although the Press had been carefully corrected, the revisal was indispensably necessary especially for the references to the extracts from books and papers— My reply to Rhett’s charge of raising a . . . against Great-Britain had not been reported by Stansbury at all.— Yet the report of the debate was imperfect without it— My arm is so disabled that I was obliged to resort to the hand of my daughter Mary to write out my remarks as I repeated them to her from Memory; and I sent them to the Intelligencer Office to be printed at the close of the day’s debate— I did not attend the house after dinner—
23. V. Saturday.

My right arm is yet sadly disabled, and my power to write more inefficient from day to day. I cannot undress or dress myself without assistance and this day for the first time since my accident could wear my coat with the left arm only in the sleeve— Elizabeth Pierce was again here this morning with the dismal tale of her Sisters and her own distress— A man by the name of Josephalso came to beg, and said he was a waiter at the Mansion house in Philadelphia when my wife was sick there in 1825. and when I was there at other Times— He too had a tale of affliction and sickness and poverty calling for compassion— Visit from Dr Thomas— I asked him if I should send to young Dr May for a Bill; he said he would as ascertain and let me know. Going to the house I called at the Intelligencer Office and asked of Mr Gales half a dozen copies of this day’s paper, containing my speech on the 8th. instt. and of the Country paper of last Tuesday containing my last Report on the Smithsonian bequest— Gales said he had already received comments on the latter.— I asked him from whom—he said he could not tell me till I have seen them— I also met there Mr Samuel Lawrence, who said he would published he believed at Boston a pamphlet edition of my speech in this morning’s Intelligencer. I advised him to wait till the next day’s debate the 9th should appear in the Intelligencer, so that the pamphlet may contain the whole debate— At the house the Speaker proposed to dispense with the business of the morning hour to dispose of the business on his table— I asked him what the business of the morning hour was? He gave me an evasive answer, and I did not press the enquiry. Mr Underwood asked to be excused from further service on the Committee upon the fight between Bynum and Rice Garland; but he alleged no satisfactory reason for his request, which the house refused to grant— Garret Davis asked a suspension of the rules for a string of Resolutions against gag-bills and executive patronage—but he could make no head-way—not even to obtain the yeas and nays on the rejection of his motion to suspend— The pre-emption bill from the Senate, upon which half a dozen questions had been taken to exclude it from the Committee of the whole, was brought up again by a motion to reconsider the vote of yesterday refusing to commit—but the house refused to reconsider, 59 to 97—a large number of Bills reported yesterday from the Committee of the whole were passed, but a debate arose upon the bill for the relief of the heirs of Matthew Lyon, which continued until the recess when Waddy Thompson was making a foolish, and ignorant speech in its favour— I did not return to the house after dinner— I lent to Mr Bond the report to the Senate of Massachusetts upon the case of the Commonwealth Bank— Mr Hoffman sent me this evening voluminous papers with a Memorial to the House of Representatives by Lysander Spooner of Athol Massachusetts against John M’Lean a judge of the Supreme Court of the United States for official misconduct Hoffman, Governor Lincoln, and Giddings have successively declined to present this Memorial, and so Mr Spooner puts the charge upon me— Miss Mease of Philadelphia was here— I missed an Evening party at Dr Frederick Halls; by a mistake—
24. IV:45. Sunday.

At the Presbyterian Church I heard this morning Mr Wood preach, from Luke 10.16. [“]He that heareth you heareth me; and he that despiseth you, despiseth me: and he that despiseth me, despiseth him that sent me.” Mr Wood in the course of the last week has been ordained Pastor of this Church, by the Presbyterian form of Ordination. He has of course accommodated himself in conformity with the organization and discipline of that Church: but his congregation is so small, it is scarcely possible they should be much longer kept together; and the doctrine of his discourse this day, that they who despise the Minister of Christ despise Christ himself had too much of allusion to his own condition; and disclosed in too much nakedness the wounded Spirit— Miss Mease, with a young French girl, miss Guillon, and Mary Cutts dined and spent the Evening with us— I attended after dinner at St. John’s church where Mr Higbee read the service for the 5th. Sunday after Easter, and a stranger preached, who Mr Hawley told me was Mr Leverett of South-Carolina He delivered his text in a tone of voice so low that I could not hear him, and his Sermon itself was a compound of frothy declamation in elegant but affected language, babbling and bursting along leaving upon the memory absolutely nothing— He reminded me of a panegyric I once heard passed upon a young Clergyman, of the highest reputation in South-Carolina— It was said of him that he rode the most spirited horse—was the best shot at a plover flying—played the best hand at whist, and wrote the best Sermon of any man in the State— How manners pass down from age to age! How much of the South Carolina character originated in Locke’s Constitution? How much in the sub-tropical climate? How much in the cultivation of Indigo, Rice and Cotton? How much (more than in all the rest) in Negro Slavery? How much in the Christian religion? and how much in Anglo-Saxon descent? These elements, mingled with the casual diversities of individual men in the progress of population have produced an average associate character—different from that of any other State in the Union—from none more than from that of its next door neighbour—North-Carolina— This character shows itself every where— In the City—in the field—by the family-fire side—in the social circle—at the Bar—in the Legislative Hall; and finally in the pulpit as I heard it this day; when not being very well, I was not in the happiest trim to receive it— Mr Richard Cutts and Mr D. D. Barnard were here this Evening. I read the memorial of Lysander Spooner, against judge M’Lean of the U.S. Supreme Court and am not a little perplexed in determining what to do with it— The complainant is a man of no ordinary talent; and the charges of a very grave character— I think there ought to be an enquiry.
25. IV:45. Monday

The recovery of the use of my arm is slow, and I write with great difficulty— Miss Cutts rode with me to the Capitol— The house was taking the yeas and nays for a Call, to make a quorum, which was effected; and then the call was superseded.— The previous question had been called last week on the motion to refer a Resolution of the Legislature of Indiana to the Committee of Ways and Means, with instructions to report a Bill for the continuation of the Cumberland road through the States of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois— The main question was ordered by yeas and nays 91 to 82— And the motion for the Instructions was lost 87 to 90— The Speaker then called for Petitions, beginning with the Territory of Iowa, and proceeding South and then East through all the Territories, and States— There were very few—the field having been swept clean last Monday— I presented a set of six abolition petitions; the last I had on hand; four of which were excluded from reception by the rule of 28 January, and the other two were laid on the table— I presented also the Memorial of Lysander Spooner, of Athol, Massachusetts complaining of the official conduct of John M’Lean a judge of the supreme Court of the United States, in depriving himself of his right of appeal from his decision as a Circuit judge in the District of Ohio, to the Supreme Court of the United States. I assigned my reasons for presenting this Memorial—said I should neither ask that it be read or printed, but merely that it be referred to the Judiciary Committee with an earnest intreaty to them to give to it their serious and undivided attention— It was so referred, at first without opposition—but afterwards Crabb of Alabama did object and the Speaker took the question a second time— Half a dozen voices answered no, but the Speaker declared the motion for reference carried— I asked leave to present the two sets of Resolutions, which I have had so long prepared— One denouncing the detention and imprisonment of the Africans of the Amistad; and the other relating to the investment of public trust funds of the United States, in Stocks of the States—objection was made even to the reading of both of them; but they were read.— Neither of them was received— I gave them both to Stansbury, with the request that they might both be published in the National Intelligencer to-morrow morning— At half past 2 came the recess— I rode home, and returned to the house after dinner— The Speaker after the call for petitions was gone through, called the Committees for Reports— Adjourned about 6 p.m. I called at Gadsby’s and saw Mr Lawrence after an interval of more than 3 months—during which he has been suffering a terrible complication of disease— He is convalescent but I found him yet lying on a Sopha, unable to sit up. But he conversed freely with me about half an hour, till Doctor Sewall came in and I retired— Miss Mease and Miss Guillon spent the Evening with us— They are going to-morrow to Virginia.
26. IV:45. Tuesday

At the House Giddings of Ohio moved a suspension of the rules for a call upon the President to inform the house whether Amos Kendall held the Office of Postmaster General on the 21st. of this month—the date of an Address to the people of the United States, which he has published in a pamphlet, signed by him, and grossly insulting to the members of Congress.— The suspension was refused by yeas and nays 60 to 102— Kendall has resigned his Office of Postmaster General upon a pretence of ill health, to become Editor of the extra-globe an electioneering periodical to be published during the pendency of the Presidential Election— And his party have been called upon to tax themselves roundly by subscriptions for this paper to support him— This abusive treatment of members of Congress, by Executive Jackalls, was begun by Andrew Jackson, who set the example of it himself— The Successor dares not follow that part of the system, but stimulates his menials to the dirty work, and the Spirit of party so entirely swallows up the Esprit du corps in Congress, that the Majority will suffer no check or rebuke upon this slanderous practice— Hillen of the Committee of Commerce, and Edward Curtis, chairman of that Committee presented Counter-reports upon memorials praying for the repeal of a law of 1838. relating to the New-York Pilots— Hillen reported a Bill to repeal the law, to which a majority of the Committee— Upon a subsequent reconsideration a majority of the Committee agreed to report against the repeal— Hillen insisted, that a Committee have no right to reconsider, for which he quoted Jefferson’s Manual, but Curtis contended that the rule applied only to Committees of the whole— This discussion continued until the expiration of the morning hour, when the orders of the day were called and the new preemption bill was taken up— The Western Spoilers with their Kinderhoek Allies have managed to keep the Bill in the House, subject to the previous question, without going into Committee of the whole upon it at-all— They had even started the previous question; but Governor Lincoln, a member of the Committee of Public Lands, had the luck to interpose a motion for a small amendment upon which he spoke very eloquently against the Bill, until the recess— I rode home to dine—and at 4. O’Clock returned to the House, where Governor Lincoln for another hour was declaiming against the Bill, and proposing a petty amendment, with which he said he would vote for the Bill, and which surrendered the whole cause— When he took his seat about twenty members started up at once— The Speaker gave the floor to John White of Kentucky a member of the Committee, who spoke till 7. O’Clock against the Bill, but with such rapidity and indistinct articulation that I could hear very little of what he said.— The Speaker then gave the floor to Hubbard of Alabama, the foggy, who said he should make a short speech to disabuse the house of the misconceptions put forth by Governor Lincoln, and then bring the discussion to a close; two speeches both against the Bill, having been made, and only his short speech in reply— A motion to adjourn failed— So I left the house and walked home, meeting young Doctor May—and John M Niles the new Postmaster General on my way.
27. IV:30 Wednesday.

After I left the House last Evening, Hubbard of Alabama made his Speech, and closed as he had announced he would by moving the previous question.
