Lewis Williams moved in vain to adjourn, and for a call of the House— The previous question was carried— Governor Lincoln’s amendment was rejected by yeas and nays 86. to 97. and the Bill was passed 120 to 64.— And thus were the public lands of the Nation delivered up to the spoilers. Cushing, Parmenter and Henry Williams voting throughout for the Bill.— The public lands are gone; and Wise after the previous question was ordered told the secret by saying, that poor settlers on the lands meant members of Congress.— This morning the first hour was occupied in pertinaciously debating whether a Committee of the House after agreeing to a report can reconsider their vote—and agree upon another—on which, Russell, Randolph, Tillinghast and Sergeant maintained the affirmative and Dromgoole the negative until the expiration of the hour— Sergeant then made a statement as Chairman of the judiciary Committee, against the memorial of Lysander Spooner which he said the Committee unanimously considered as totally groundless and unfounded.— There were some expressions in the Statement which seemed to imply a censure upon me for presenting the memorial— I rose to remark upon them; but Alford of Georgia got the floor, and moved a reconsideration of the Bill which had passed last Night, and for the passage of which he had voted— The Bill, which had already passed the Senate was now gone there to be signed by the Vice-President; and it was made a question whether a reconsideration could in such case be moved— While this was in debate Burke from the Committee of enrolled bills reported it for the signature of the Speaker, who decided that the motion to reconsider was in order; and this decision was upon appeal sustained by the house— Alford proceeded in his vehement and humorous manner to prove over again, what Governor Lincoln and White of Kentucky had consumed all yesterday in demonstrating; that the Bill was an effectual surrender of all the public lands to the land-jobbing gamblers—but it was in vain—he was answered with the previous question and yeas and nays 96 to 103. against reconsideration— It was past 2 O’Clock, when the house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the Independent Treasury-Bill, Linn Banks in the Chair— Cushing resumed his argument against it till the recess— I then rode home, taking with me my books for reference on the revenue bill debate.— I returned between 4 and 5. and found Cushing, drawing to the close of his Speech, in which he mentioned with approbation my Son’s Articles in the Boston Courier on the Government and the Country— He was followed by Lowell against the Bill. Adjournment at 6. Call on Mr Lawrence— Richard Cutts—and Walter Hellen were here this Evening.
28. IV:45— Thursday

I attended this morning at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures; but no quorum was formed— Slade, Tillinghast and Dromgoole were there— Absent Davis, Nisbett, Mitchell, Eastman and Worthington— Numerous Memorials have been referred by the house to the Committee since their last Meeting, but without a Quorum they could not be taken up for consideration— At the House, the morning hour was consumed in further debating the question whether a standing Committee of the House, after having agreed upon a report, can reconsider their own report, and present to the house another— Tillinghast produced the authority from the Journal of the English house of Commons of 5. June 1607. against the right to reconsider—he thought it antiquated; but Dromgoole insisted that its antiquity was the best proof of its propriety and wisdom— Ryall one of the spurious members from New Jersey, made a speech rather in favour of the second Report than upon the right of the Committee to make it; and Dickerson another of the same false delegation took the floor just as the morning hour expired— Triplet of Kentucky, moved a suspension of the rules, to introduce a bill supplemental, to the supplemental pre-emption act definitively passed yesterday— Triplet said he was authorised by the chairman of the Committee on the public Lands to offer this Bill— Lincoln asked who gave the Chairman to confer such favours? Triplet answered it was no favour but a right— The Speaker advised Triplet to wait till to-morrow; and he accordingly withdrew his motion to suspend the rules, and gave notice that he would ask leave to bring his bill to morrow— It is a stoppage at the spigot, after the head of barrel has been knocked out— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Linn Banks in the Chair Independent Treasury Bill— Lowell of Maine took up his hum-drum discourse of invective against banks, raked and scraped from Van Buren’s and Jacksons’s Messages, and the mobbed Newspapers for the last three years; and thus he continued droning till the recess— I rode home, determining not to return to hear the peroration of this modern Demosthenes, but to write out part of my Speech of the 9th instt. Instead of which I found myself after dinner weary and drowsy, and took a Siesta of two hours after which I could write nothing but the remnant of the journal of yesterday. Mr George Gilmer heretofore a member of the house from Georgia, and since then a Governor of that State was in the house this morning and gave me a cordial greeting. I asked Sergeant if the Judiciary Committee meant to censure me for presenting Lysander Spooner’s Memorial, they would distinctly say so in their report, and I would meet it. Dr Thomas, Mary Cutts and Virginia Tayloe were here this Evening— I am in musing meditation Night and morning upon the wants of Man.
29. V. Friday

My helpless and almost lifeless arm disqualifies me much for writing; and leaves the activity of the mind to turn and prey upon itself. In my sleepless and in many of my wakeful hours, I turn to my versification of the Wants of Man—to which I this morning added four Stanza’s, making in all 22. I wrote it first in 12—and have subsequently added some of the best Stanza’s but in coming to details I find them susceptible of multiplication ad infinitum The consequence is that the poem is already too long.— Trifles should always be short.— I had forgotten to mention that on Tuesday Morning Mr Trist called on me and left with me a large volume of Manuscript correspondence relating to the charges against him; and Mr Davis our Senator sent me another parcel of papers on the same subject— Captain Wendell has arrested Mr Trist here upon an action of Trespass, laying his damages at 30,000 dollars. This morning on my way to the House, I called at Miss Polk’s boarding house, and there saw Mr Smith the preceptor of the Hingham Academy, Mrs Smith, and Miss Catherine Thaxter, who are here upon a short Summer excursion— At the house they were taking the yeas and nays on a motion of Chinn to suspend the rules for a Call on the Postmaster General, for documents relating to the defalcation of a Postmaster at Mobile—77 to 69. no suspension— Anderson gave notice that he would next Monday ask leave to introduce his bill supplemental to the new pre-emption law. John W. Jones moved as usual the suspension of the rules to take up the Independent Treasury-Bill—106 to 84. not two thirds. I foretell that the majority for this bill will be 25.— The house then went upon private business and soon fell foul of the bill for allowing double rations to Daniel Parker while he was adjutant General— The old grudge of John C. Calhoun against him. This was debated till the recess— I rode home; and did not return to the house this afternoon— I had a long conversation with Governor Gilmer upon old forgotten political manoeuvering and intrigues.— Mr W. C. Preston afterwards came to me, and referring to my offer in March 1825 to W. H. Crawford, that he should remain Secretary of the Treasury, asked me if I knew that the answer which I received from him was not the answer which he first wrote, on receiving my note. I said I did not— He said Mr Crawford’s first answer was kinder in its expressions and placed his retirement from the Treasury Department, entirely on the ground of his ill health— He said that Mr Crawford’s original answer still existed, and he could procure the original or a copy of it for me— I infer that Gilmer has this paper and that they have some need or occasion for testimony from me.— This whole afternoon, Mary wrote at my dictation upon the report of my Speeches on the 9th. instt. upon the 9th. Section of my revenue bill— Mr and Mrs Smith, Miss Thaxter and Mr John Connell were here this evening.
30. V. Saturday.

On reaching the house this morning I was informed that the Bill for allowing double rations to General Daniel Parker had been passed last Evening, and that excepting that, and a call of the house which had occupied two hours nothing else had been done— The debate on the question whether a Committee of the House after agreeing to make a report can reconsider this decision, and present a report of an opposite character was brought to a close, by the previous question— The report presented by Hillen, accompanied by a Bill repealing the Pilot-Law, was accepted by yeas and nays 86 to 83. and the true report of the majority of the Committee, offered by Chairman Curtis was thereby rejected, and this vote was carried by the change of three democrats, Carr, Galbraith and Henry Williams who when their names were called answered no, and after the roll was called through, changed their recounted votes, ranged themselves with the rest of their party, and reversed the decision of the house which they had just contributed to form.— What an illustration of the principle thus settled that a Committee of the House cannot reconsider its own vote— Atherton after the failure of a motion to suspend the rules to take up the subtreasury bill, gave notice that he would next Monday move to rescind the rule itself which requires a majority of two thirds to suspend the rules.— Some question arose about the Bill reported by Hillen to repeal the Pilot Act of March 1837—but the hour had expired—the orders of the day were called; and Galbraith moved a reconsideration of the vote of last evening by which the bill for allowing double rations to General Daniel Parker had passed. Then followed a debate of an hour and a half upon the question of reconsideration then a vote by yeas and nays oftoto reconsider; and then a vote oftolaid the bill on the table— Another Bill was then taken up and trifled with till the recess— Professor the Storm-maker Espy had called on me this morning; told me he was going to England, and asked me for a Letter of introduction to any of my friends— I gave him one to Mr George Joy— A fisticuff fight and a breaking of canes over each other’s heads took place just at the moment of the recess, between Kenneth Rayner and William Montgomery both members of the House, from North-Carolina— They have been reviling each other in the Globe Newspaper for the last fortnight or three weeks— I took Mr Saltonstall home and he returned with me after dinner; but before we reached the Capitol they had met and adjourned without making a Quorum—
31. V. Sunday.

Miss Mease and Miss Guillon having returned from their visit in Virginia, were here last Evening and dined and spent this day here— Mr James, the member of the House from Pennsylvania with Mrs James, and Mrs Cooper wife of James Cooper another member from the same State were also here last Evening, and I had a long visit from Mr Alexander Vattemare, who left with me a budget of complimentary Letters, and puffing newspaper paragraphs about his great invention of duplicate exchanges, and to which he wishes an additional one from me. This morning I attended public worship at the Capitol where Dr Bates delivered a Discourse upon Education from Ephesians 6.4. [“]And ye, fathers, provoke not your children to wrath: but bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord.” Notice was given yesterday in the National Intelligencer that this Sermon would be specially addressed to Parents— It was a plain, sensible, judicious discourse, containing some of the most obvious ideas upon education, and the most memorable passage of which was a quotation from Bishop Butler— Dr Bates declares personal chastisement to be in no case whatever necessary. He disapproves alike too much rigour and too much laxity of discipline— He recommends especially the use of reason with children, and earnestly insists upon the practice of using the Bible as a School book—in the vernacular language at the primary schools—in the original tongues at the Colleges— He promised another Sermon upon intellectual education. After dinner at St. John’s Church, two clergymen officiated for Mr Hawley—Mr Davis, settled somewhere in Maryland, and Mr Marcus, an Englishman, and converted Jew. They divided between them the reading of the Evening service for the Sunday after Ascension day—and Mr Davis preached from Acts 17.11. “These were more noble than those in Thessalonica in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the Scriptures daily, whether those things were so. 12. Therefore many of them believed: also of honourable women which were Greeks, and of men, not a few.” Miss Guillon, with Mary Cutts and my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa, were with me in the pew. While I was out Mr Clay and Mr Tillinghast paid visits at my house— Mr Robert Greenhow, Translator at the Department of State had also paid me a visit before dinner. He is one of the members of the new Scientific Society, and sent me the day after the second Meeting at Mr Poinsett’s, a work of his upon Tripoli— Mr King the Painter, Mrs Talbot and her daughter were also here this Evening.
Day— I rise about 5 O’Clock, with my right arm disabled and get half dressed with the aid of Mrs Goode. Read till breakfast at 8. To the house at 11.— Recess at half past two. Evening at home.
